text: Hey, everyone. My current client allows a lot of stakeholders to weight in with comments in Google Docs. Most of it is necessary with everyone remote right now.  Do any of you have rules/guidelines for using Google Docs for this sort of collaboration? I'm thinking about things like: when is it OK to resolve a comment? Do you always tag a specific person in a comment? Do you always keep the comment open so others can see that the discussion happened? TIA.

text:
I follow a simple format when multiple stakeholders are editing in a single document:

1) Allow all of them a stipulated time to make suggestions/comments.

2) Edit based off of those suggestions, mark them in different colors and tag the individual.

3) Repeat. 

This system works for me. It's simple and straightforward.

text:
In addition to what Deb said, I also set clear expectations for the type of feedback we're gathering at each stage.

If, for example, the content has already gone through developmental editing and been reviewed/approved internally, feedback should focus on how clear and factual the information is and while suggestions for significant structural changes are welcome, they can't expect to see them implemented without delaying the deadline.

text:
Within my team at at a major eCommerce site (not Amazon) , we use Google Docs extensively and as my team is like air traffic control for global positioning it can be tedious.

At a very high level with our emails for example, I create the copy based on a request and then the Product Marketing Manager will review.

We then assign a main POC to own content reviews for the regional team (e.g. France, Italy, Spain, etc.). I then engage with them to adjust messaging, loop in the PMM when necessary.

We also have stakeholders such as Product and Customer Service. The former, we provide specific copy blocks for approval. They don't review the entire doc. Customer Service does a full review.

After those approvals, we get Director (sometimes VP, C-Level approval). Then it goes to legal (an entirely different discussion).

After legal approval, the content goes live, or it is sent for translation, then local counsel again.

In terms of resolving comments. I generally give everyone outside of my team comment access only. Before resolving comments, I'll leave a "noted" or "closing based on email discussion," etc. so there's clear context.

To be perfectly honest, my team simply tries to keep reviewers to as few as possible and there's a clear POC.

I interact with 70+ people every week so it's impossible to share clear steps. Having a clear POC for each division  really is all we've needed to maintain order.
